firstChapter.htmlHeader: Pre-patellar bursitis: Summary
firstChapter.htmlStringContent:
• The pre-patellar bursa lies between the anterior surface of the patella and the skin. It facilitates free movement of the skin over the patella during movements of the leg.
  • Bursitis occurs when the bursa becomes inflamed leading to increased fluid production and swelling of the bursal sac.
  • Bursitis can be categorised into:
    • Non-septic — sterile inflammation of the bursa. Non-infectious causes of bursitis include trauma, overuse, gout, and systemic disease such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and sarcoid.
    • Septic — infection of the bursal sac with micro-organisms (usually bacteria). Complications of septic pre-patellar bursitis include septic arthritis, skin infection and necrosis, osteomyelitis, and sepsis.
  • Pre-patellar bursitis should be suspected if there is:
    • Localized swelling over the patella, which may be tender, red and/or warm.
    • Fluctuance (the swelling is movable and compressible) — the patella may not be palpable with large collections of fluid.
    • A normal range of joint movement (depending on the size of the fluid collection).
    • Maximal discomfort at extreme flexion of the knee (when the swollen bursa is compressed).
    • A history of preceding trauma or bursal disease (from previous traumatic bursitis, rheumatoid arthritis, or gout).
  • Differentiation between septic and non-septic bursitis is difficult and aspiration may be needed to exclude infection. Clinical features that may indicate septic bursitis include:
    • Systemic features such as fever, nausea or malaise.
    • Pain and tenderness to palpation.
    • Erythema and overlying warmth.
    • Local cellulitis.
    • A visible port of entry for micro-organisms such as abrasion or laceration over the bursa.
    • Immunocompromised state.
  • If a confident diagnosis of non-septic bursitis can be made, the person should be advised on conservative measures such as:
    • Resting the knee.
    • Modification or avoidance of activities which worsen symptoms (such as prolonged kneeling or pressure over the knee).
    • Application of ice.
    • Compression.
    • Elevation.
    • Simple analgesia (such as paracetamol or non-steroidal anti-inflammatories).
  • If septic bursitis cannot be excluded from the clinical features, bursal fluid should be aspirated using a sterile aspiration technique (if the expertise and equipment are available) and sent for analysis.
    • If the expertise and equipment for aspiration are not available in primary care, urgent discussion with orthopaedics is recommended.
    • Antibiotic treatment is recommended for suspected septic bursitis and should be started while awaiting sensitivities from the laboratory — antibiotic should be changed, if necessary, when sensitivities become available.
    • Conservative measures (as for non-septic bursitis) should be advised in addition to antibiotic treatment.
    • Clear safety netting and close follow up are essential if septic bursitis is treated in primary care.
  • Admission to hospital is required if the person:
    • Is systemically unwell (for example fever over 38ºC, tachycardia, hypotension or increased respiratory rate).
    • Has severe septic bursitis or severe infection of the surrounding tissues.
    • Is immunocompromised or has other serious comorbidities, such as diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Has developed an abscess requiring incision and drainage.
  • Urgent referral to, or discussion with, orthopaedics is required if:
    • The person has septic bursitis and is not responding, or responding inadequately, to antibiotic treatment — admission may be needed.
  • Referral to orthopaedics (with urgency depending on clinical judgement) should be made if the person has:
    • Recurrent septic bursitis.
    • A chronically discharging sinus.
    • Non-septic chronic bursitis, which is not responding to conservative measures, or, is associated with significant recurrent swelling and/or pain.
